articles.headline: China Dangled Rebates to Lure People to Spend. It’s Not Enough.
articles.snippet: China’s leaders vowed to kick-start spending by offering subsidies for households to buy cars and appliances. But many consumers aren’t biting.
articles.abstract: China’s leaders vowed to kick-start spending by offering subsidies for households to buy cars and appliances. But many consumers aren’t biting.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four months ago, China’s leaders announced what seemed like a straightforward and proven plan to recharge the economy: Subsidize consumers who want to replace old cars and household appliances.

articles.headline: Boeing Agrees to Buy Spirit AeroSystems, a Longtime Supplier
articles.snippet: The multibillion-dollar deal will reverse a decision the plane maker made two decades ago to outsource production of key parts to independent suppliers.
articles.abstract: The multibillion-dollar deal will reverse a decision the plane maker made two decades ago to outsource production of key parts to independent suppliers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boeing said on Monday that it had agreed to buy a major supplier, Spirit AeroSystems, ending a nearly two-decade experiment in outsourcing production of major components of its commercial planes, including the body of the 737 Max and parts of the 767, 777 and 787.

articles.headline: Pay for Lawyers Is So High People Are Comparing It to the N.B.A.
articles.snippet: Enormous pay packages are popping up for top lawyers, especially those favored by well-heeled private equity clients.
articles.abstract: Enormous pay packages are popping up for top lawyers, especially those favored by well-heeled private equity clients.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hotshot Wall Street lawyers are now so in demand that bidding wars between firms for their services can resemble the frenzy among teams to sign star athletes.
articles.byline: By Maureen Farrell and Anupreeta Das

articles.headline: Palestinian Fighters in West Bank Seek to Emulate Hamas in Gaza
articles.snippet: In the towns of Tulkarm and Jenin, armed militants are flocking to more hard-line factions, such as Hamas and Islamic Jihad, while the Israeli military tries to rein them in.
articles.abstract: In the towns of Tulkarm and Jenin, armed militants are flocking to more hard-line factions, such as Hamas and Islamic Jihad, while the Israeli military tries to rein them in.
articles.lead_paragraph: The alleys are cast in permanent semidarkness, covered by black nylon tarpaulins to hide the Palestinian fighters there from Israeli drones overhead. Green Hamas flags and banners commemorating “martyrs” hang from the buildings, many badly damaged during Israeli raids and airstrikes to try to tamp down a growing militancy in the territory, fueled by the war in Gaza.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Sergey Ponomarev

articles.headline: The Road to a Crisis: How Democrats Let Biden Glide to Renomination
articles.snippet: An 81-year-old candidate and no Plan B. “How did we get here?” one leading Democrat asks. The answer is complicated.
articles.abstract: An 81-year-old candidate and no Plan B. “How did we get here?” one leading Democrat asks. The answer is complicated.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of Thursday’s presidential debate, as Jill Biden led President Biden off the stage, former Senator Claire McCaskill, the Missouri Democrat, raised what she called a “hard and heartbreaking” question.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: Supreme Court Declines to Rule on Tech Platforms’ Free Speech Rights
articles.snippet: The justices unanimously returned two cases, which concerned state laws that supporters said were aimed at “Silicon Valley censorship,” to lower courts. Critics had said the laws violated the sites’ First Amendment rights.
articles.abstract: The justices unanimously returned two cases, which concerned state laws that supporters said were aimed at “Silicon Valley censorship,” to lower courts. Critics had said the laws violated the sites’ First Amendment rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court sidestepped a definitive resolution on Monday in a pair of cases challenging state laws aimed at curbing the power of social media companies to moderate content. The ruling left in limbo an effort by Republicans who had promoted the legislation as a remedy to what they say is a bias against conservatives.
articles.byline: By Abbie VanSickle, David McCabe and Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Supreme Court Says Trump Has Some Immunity in Election Case
articles.snippet: The ruling makes a distinction between official actions of a president, which have immunity, and those of a private citizen. In dissent, the court’s liberals lament a vast expansion of presidential power.
articles.abstract: The ruling makes a distinction between official actions of a president, which have immunity, and those of a private citizen. In dissent, the court’s liberals lament a vast expansion of presidential power.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that former President Donald J. Trump is entitled to substantial immunity from prosecution on charges of trying to overturn the last election, a blockbuster decision in the heat of the 2024 campaign that vastly expanded presidential power.
